conclusion: To find the magnitude of the pressure exerted by the sled on the ground, we need to determine the normal force acting on the sled.
The normal force is the force exerted by the ground perpendicular to the surface, which balances the vertical forces acting on the sled.
Calculate gravitational force acting on sled and child: F_gravity = (m_child + m_sled) * g = 400 N.
The pulling force exerted by the adult is 100 N at an angle of 37 degrees above the horizontal.
Resolve pulling force into horizontal component: F_horizontal = F * cos(37) = 80 N.
Resolve pulling force into vertical component: F_vertical = F * sin(37) = 60 N.
Since the sled moves at a constant speed, the net vertical force must be zero.
Calculate normal force: N = F_gravity - F_vertical = 340 N.
Pressure is defined as force per unit area.
The problem asks for the magnitude of the pressure exerted by the sled on the ground, interpreted as the normal force.
The magnitude of the pressure exerted by the sled on the ground is equal to the normal force.
The magnitude of the pressure exerted by the sled on the ground is 340 N.
